ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned about the evolution of many aspects of the Indian Ocean World including trade, diaspora, climate change, religion, empires, and colonization.
Learning about global history from an Indian Ocean framework.

I gained a general understanding of the timeline and themes in the history of the Indian Ocean basin, from medieval times to the present day. I'd never taken a history class like this that was focused on an entire ocean region; it offered us the ability to look beyond national boundaries and think critically about how those boundaries were constructed and larger patterns, or breaks from patterns, in the region over a long timescale.

The Indian Ocean World helped expand my knowledge on trade, diaspora, religion, labor and so on. It provided me with some extremely useful readings and discussions that helped think through some key concepts such as the relationship between connectivity, exchange of knowledge and nation building among others. I have developed a keen interest in South Asian Studies due to the readings provided by prof. Amrith.

Prof Amrith focused on the big ideas of the Indian Ocean, dipping into specific historical moments or issues, but keeping the content intellectually broad and therefore accessible to all majors. I learned how to think about the important region of the Indian Ocean, but even more to think about history is recovered, constructed, and manipulated.
Learned about the cultural history of the Indian Ocean -- religions, politics, language, etc.

Course covered all of Indian Ocean history, from 1000 to present. Indian Ocean included coast of India, Southeast Asia, Arabian Peninsula, and East African coast. Topics included religious encounters, empires/colonialism, labor, port cities, gender/family, nationalism, decolonization, cultures, and geopolitics. Lots of broad lectures followed by parsing more complex, specific material.
I learned a lot about history, specifically a historical approach that decenters nations and focuses on people and their interactions.
I learned how much of a gap there is in my geographic history knowledge

I learned about the historical development of the Indian Ocean from pre-colonial times to the 20th century. Some of the themes included port cities, migration, labor, climate change, and decolonization. Really the class is about understanding how many of the formative themes of world history have developed, in some way shape or form, through the various historical interactions  that took place in the Indian Ocean.
the history of the Indian Ocean world starting from the 1600s until the mid twentieth century through a thematic perspective
I learned a lot about the history of South and Southeast Asia, in addition to exploring questions about primary source bias and how to "read the archive."

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a great class. The low workload allowed me to focus on learning the material without the stress of applying everything to assignments.
The Indian Ocean provided a very compelling framework to learn about history. Each week's topic and lectures tend to be quite broad and general, but that is to be expected from a survey class.

I thought this was a fantastic class -- good readings, great lectures, engaging conversations, a really interesting and important approach to think about telling and understanding a regional, oceanic history. I appreciated Professor Amrith's lectures with lots of opportunity for conversation and student input, and the optional Wednesday sessions were great to get the feel of a seminar in a larger lecture class. I wish that we'd talked about the readings a little more in lecture or section; they were interesting!
This course has touched upon so many different aspects of the Indian ocean world that it has proved to be extremely useful for an expanded understanding of interconnectivity.
Interesting material but somehow many of the ideas we talked about in class seem a little generalized

Strengths: great teaching staff that was very flexible and accommodating.
Weaknesses: there were a lot of mini recorded lectures that ended up substituting live lectures. I think this won't be a problem post-COVID, but the mix was kind of weird.

Strengths: Professor Amrith is a fantastic lecturer. Course addressed topics that I had little knowledge of beforehand, not too difficult, super thought-provoking, addressed a variety of topics that raised important discussion. 

Weaknesses: Would have preferred a beginning that provided a bit more background on the basics. Wish it was a bit less expansive: I loved learning about everything but sometimes it felt like too much ground (or sea) to cover. That said, its hard to argue what to cut, because there was so much fascinating stuff and cultures I never had any interaction with: Plantation societies, Victorian values translated to odd legal codes, military history, Cairo Genizah, Mosque architecture... it makes me feel like Im on the bachelor and cant decide who to cut. But overall it would have been better (I think) to prioritize a bit more depth and a bit less breadth. Still a great course though, highly recommend. Also, would appreciate if slides had spelled out the proper nouns of places/people - because many of the names/places are not English language, it's sometimes difficult to spell correctly and then I cant look it up later.
Great overview of many themes, and prof Amrith is so smart and thoughtful

Strength: Prof. Amrith for sure. Amazing professor who actually cares about students and the content. Another Strength: the content is amazingly interesting and the workload isnt too bad. 

Weakness: online lectures are just always tough, and the readings could be a little dense sometimes.
course was really facilitated well geographically and temporally, because this is a huge and broad course but was tabulated well
I think the syllabus is organized well, thematically and chronologically. I also really liked the ability to make the essays personalized to our interests.
everything about this course was great! no weaknesses.

Strengths: Sunil Amrith is a gem, great readings, interesting and not-too-long prerecorded lectures, interactive live lectures, fantastic TAs

Weaknesses: this is very much an intro course/broad survey class, which isn't a weakness per se, but it is worth noting

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Amrith was very kind in adjusting the class schedule throughout the semester, shifting formats, and providing a manageable assignment workload during a difficult semester.

I appreciated the breakout room conversations, although they were a little hit-or-miss depending on how chatty/caught up on the readings the people in your breakout room were. I really liked the Wednesday smaller group conversations since they was optional and drew a group that was all eager to talk about that week's topic; I learned a lot from my peers' questions and interests in those smaller settings.

The recorded lectures were very helpful and helped me stay tuned in for the live lectures and I think this is a great method especially during the pandemic. Prof. Amrith was also very empathetic and helpful which helped  in absorbing the weeks' readings and coming to class prepared.

Prof Amrith handled remote learning exceptionally well. His balance of recorded and live lectures, the inclusion of breakout rooms, his reduction of the workload without lessening the learning. . . he succeeded in creating a rigorous but comfortable classroom space.
The breakout rooms were too long, particularly when nobody really felt like talking; I would have preferred more lecture
this class was one of the most accessible classes during COVID.

Professor Amrith worked tirelessly to make the course as engaging as possible. A good amount of student participation in class through breakout rooms, polls, and infographics. Corresponded on an individual basis and encouraged conversation and questions.
I think the zoom format was interesting, but there was a lot of reliance on breakout rooms

I appreciated being able to watch pre-recorded lectures on my own time, while class time was reserved for things like guest lectures or discussions that built on the pre-recorded lectures and reading. I do think that going into breakout rooms could have been modified--I think we had too much time and too few people.

I liked that the pre-recorded lectures were short and that Wednesday class was made optional during the second half of the course. Both of these decision speak to how generous and considerate Professor Amrith was when designing the class, taking into account the exhaustion of the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes--it was a great introduction to the history of the Indian Ocean World as someone with no history background. You learn a lot but the workload is super low.
Would greatly recommend to anyone interested in learning about global history from a less Euro-centric perspective.
Absolutely recommend. I learned so much, got so much out of the readings, discussions and lectures, and thoroughly appreciated Professor Amriths approach to the semester. A fantastic class.

Yes, yes, and yes! I came in knowing very little about the Indian Ocean world and came away with a much better understanding of the themes and patterns that have shaped and continue to shape the region. We didn't focus much on specific dates and events, but I now have a long-scale, sweeping sense of the region and was exposed to a vision of historical analysis beyond area studies or studies of particular countries. It's a great class if you're interested in history that transcends national borders and instead focuses on places and how they both influence and are influenced by human activity.

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in Asian Studies as well as port cities, trading etc. It was a mind opening class as it touched upon a varied number of topics making it super helpful!

Yes! Prof Amrith is one of those absurdly intelligent Yale profs who somehow remains down-to-earth, accessible, and kind. His lectures are fun to listen to, the ideas and sources and stories he brings into class are intellectually interesting and impactful outside of the classroom. This class is welcoming to those who are not History majors.
Yes, the topics are interesting, and the professor cares about student well-being
Yes definitely!!!
I think yes. The course was pretty interesting and very low stress.
Yes absolutely! A great class about an understudied region of the world that is important to know about for geopolitics, climate change, migration, etc.
Yes!

Yes, I would recommend this course to other students for the opportunity to learn from a great professor and study a topic which is broad but somewhat underrepresented (maybe this is a personal weakness but I had basically no knowledge of Indian Ocean history before the class).
Yes!
Yes!! Great course and great professor and great content.
If you have no historical knowledge of this area, take this course

I think this is a fantastic course to learn if you're interested in world history or in the history of certain countries/regions that surround the Indian Ocean. I'd also recommend if you're just curious about a part of the world that you just haven't studied before.
Absolutely, especially if its Professor Amrith!
YES!!
Yes, definitely. It's great for a student who doesn't know much about the Indian Ocean World but would like to learn about it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Some recorded lecture, some virtual live lecture, some virtual live discussion sections
Combined with recorded lectures, optional Wednesday lecture.
Recorded lecture, live seminar/section

We had one live virtual lecture each week (Mondays); the other live class meeting was an optional, virtual smaller conversation (Wednesdays). Professor Amrith also posted short lecture segments to watch before the week's Monday lecture.
Prof. Amrith also had recorded lectures every week alongside live virtual lectures.
Recorded and live lectures, discussion section
also pre-recorded lectures
Recorded lectures, as well virtual office hours and virtual section weekly
Some recorded lectures as well.
Recorded lectures as well
This course had a variety of recorded lectures, live lectures/question and answer sessions, and discussion section.
Recorded lectures with live virtual segments
N/A
We also had a 50min section on Fridays.
and recorded lecture.
Recorded and virtual live lectures
Kind of a flipped classroom-- we'd have some of the lectures pre-recorded and discuss in breakout rooms in class
Learning also included pre-recorded lectures to be viewed before live lecture.
both in live virtual lectures and prerecorded lectures
also weekly recorded courses
live virtual lecture, pre-recorded lecture, live virtual section
